explicatoryContent.introduction: Scientists are curious people who ask questions about the world around them. But not all questions can be answered with an experiment. In this topic, you will learn how to ask questions that CAN be tested, plan fair experiments, and choose the right tools to collect information.
keyPoints: Testable questions can be answered by doing an experiment
A hypothesis is your prediction of what will happen
Variables are things that can change in an experiment
A fair test only changes one thing at a time
The right equipment helps you collect accurate information

vocabulary.definition: A question that can be answered by doing an experiment
Your prediction or educated guess about what will happen
Something that can change or be changed in an experiment
The thing you change on purpose in an experiment
The thing you measure or observe that changes as a result
Things you keep the same to make the test fair
An experiment where only one thing is changed at a time
Tools and materials used to do an experiment

analogies.analogy: Think of baking cookies. If you want to know if more sugar makes cookies sweeter, you only change the amount of sugar (independent variable) and taste the result (dependent variable). You keep everything else the same - the oven temperature, cooking time, and other ingredients (controlled variables).

sections.title: Asking Testable Questions
sections.content: Good science starts with good questions. A testable question is one you can answer by doing an experiment. Instead of asking 'Why is the sky blue?' (which needs research), you might ask 'Does the colour of light affect how well plants grow?' (which you can test). Testable questions often start with 'Does...', 'How does...', or 'What effect does...'.

sections.title: Making a Hypothesis
sections.content: A hypothesis is your prediction about what will happen in your experiment. It's based on what you already know. A good hypothesis includes what you think will happen AND why. For example: 'I think plants will grow taller in blue light because plants use light for energy.'

sections.title: Understanding Variables
sections.content: Every experiment has three types of variables. The independent variable is what YOU change on purpose. The dependent variable is what changes as a result - it's what you measure. Controlled variables are everything else that you keep the same to make sure your test is fair.

sections.title: Planning a Fair Test
sections.content: A fair test only changes ONE thing at a time. If you change more than one thing, you won't know which change caused the result. Write down each step of your experiment so someone else could repeat it exactly the same way.

sections.title: Choosing Equipment
sections.content: Different experiments need different tools. Think about what you need to measure - length, mass, time, temperature, or volume. Choose equipment that measures accurately enough for your experiment. A stopwatch measures time, a ruler measures length, and a thermometer measures temperature.

caseStudy.title: Testing Paper Planes
caseStudy.scenario: Year 7 student Mia loves making paper planes. She wonders if the type of paper affects how far they fly. She decides to investigate this question scientifically.
observations: Mia makes the same paper plane design using three different types of paper: newspaper, copy paper, and cardboard
She throws each plane from the same height with the same throwing motion
She measures how far each plane flies using a tape measure
She repeats each throw three times to make sure her results are reliable
She records all her measurements in a table

questions.question: What is Mia's testable question?
questions.answer: Does the type of paper affect how far a paper plane flies?

questions.question: What is the independent variable in Mia's experiment?
questions.answer: The type of paper (newspaper, copy paper, cardboard)

questions.question: What is the dependent variable?
questions.answer: The distance the plane flies

questions.question: Name two things Mia kept the same (controlled variables)
questions.answer: The plane design, the throwing height, and the throwing motion

caseStudy.realWorldConnection: Scientists and engineers use the same process when designing real aircraft. They test one variable at a time to understand how changes affect flight performance.
caseStudy.modelAnalysis: Mia's investigation follows the scientific method. By only changing the paper type and keeping everything else the same, she can be confident that any difference in flight distance is caused by the paper, not something else.

remember.question: What is a hypothesis?
options: A question you want to answer
A prediction about what will happen
The result of an experiment
A type of equipment

feedback.correct: Correct! A hypothesis is your prediction or educated guess about what you think will happen in an experiment.
feedback.incorrect: Not quite. A hypothesis is a prediction about what you think will happen before you do the experiment.

remember.question: Which type of variable do you deliberately change in an experiment?
options: Dependent variable
Controlled variable
Independent variable
Measured variable

feedback.correct: That's right! The independent variable is the one you deliberately change to see what effect it has.
feedback.incorrect: Think again. The independent variable is what YOU change on purpose in the experiment.

understand.question: Why is it important to only change one variable at a time in an experiment?
options: To save time
To use less equipment
To know what caused the result
To make the experiment easier

feedback.correct: Exactly! If you change only one thing, you can be sure that any changes you observe are caused by that one thing.
feedback.incorrect: Think about it - if you change multiple things, how would you know which one caused any changes you see?

understand.question: Which question is testable through an experiment?
options: Why do stars twinkle?
Which fertiliser helps plants grow tallest?
What is the most beautiful flower?
When was electricity discovered?

feedback.correct: Correct! This question can be tested by growing plants with different fertilisers and measuring their height.
feedback.incorrect: A testable question is one you can answer by doing an experiment and measuring results.

apply.question: A student wants to test if temperature affects how quickly sugar dissolves in water. What should be the independent variable?
options: The amount of sugar
The temperature of the water
How fast the sugar dissolves
The type of container

feedback.correct: Yes! The water temperature is what the student will change (independent variable) to see its effect on dissolving time.
feedback.incorrect: Remember, the independent variable is what you deliberately change. The student wants to test the effect of temperature.

apply.question: You want to investigate if the length of a pendulum affects its swing time. What should you keep the same?
options: The length of the pendulum
The weight of the pendulum bob and release height
The time it takes to swing
The number of swings

feedback.correct: Correct! The weight of the bob and the release height should stay the same (controlled variables) while you change the length.
feedback.incorrect: Controlled variables are things you keep the same. The length is what you're changing, and the swing time is what you're measuring.

analyse.question: A student tested if music helps plants grow. They played music to Plant A in a sunny window and kept Plant B in silence in a dark cupboard. Why is this not a fair test?
options: They should have used more plants
They changed two things - music AND light
They didn't use the right equipment
They should have measured the plants more often

feedback.correct: Exactly right! By changing both music AND light conditions, the student can't tell which factor affected plant growth.
feedback.incorrect: Look at what was different between the two plants - they had different music AND different light conditions.

analyse.question: An experiment was repeated 5 times and gave results of: 12, 13, 11, 35, 12 seconds. What might explain the unusual result?
options: The experiment worked perfectly
There might have been an error in the fourth trial
All the results are equally valid
The hypothesis was wrong

feedback.correct: Good analysis! The result of 35 is very different from the others, suggesting an error or unusual condition during that trial.
feedback.incorrect: Look at the pattern - four results are around 11-13, but one is 35. This unusual result suggests something went wrong.

evaluate.question: A student's hypothesis was that cold water would freeze faster than hot water. Their experiment showed hot water froze first. What should they conclude?
options: Their hypothesis was wrong
They should ignore the results
They should change their data to match their hypothesis
The experiment must have had an error

feedback.correct: Correct! Scientists accept when their hypothesis is not supported by evidence. This is actually an interesting real phenomenon called the Mpemba effect!
feedback.incorrect: In science, we accept our results even when they don't match our predictions. We don't change data to match what we expected.

evaluate.question: Which improvement would make an experiment more reliable?
options: Using fancier equipment
Only doing the experiment once
Repeating the experiment several times
Not recording results that seem wrong

feedback.correct: Yes! Repeating an experiment helps confirm that your results are consistent and not just due to chance or error.
feedback.incorrect: Reliability comes from getting consistent results. Repeating an experiment helps confirm your findings are real.

create.question: Which would be the best hypothesis for investigating plant growth?
options: Plants are interesting
I will grow some plants
Plants in red pots will grow faster than plants in blue pots
Plants given more water will grow taller because water is needed for photosynthesis

feedback.correct: Excellent! This hypothesis states a clear prediction AND gives a reason based on scientific knowledge.
feedback.incorrect: The best hypothesis makes a clear, testable prediction and explains the reasoning behind it.

create.question: A student wants to design an experiment about paper towel absorbency. What would be the best first step?
options: Buy lots of different paper towels
Write a testable question about what they want to find out
Start pouring water on paper towels
Write up the conclusion

feedback.correct: That's right! Every good experiment starts with a clear, testable question that guides the whole investigation.
feedback.incorrect: Good experiments start with planning. The first step is to ask a clear, testable question.

unistructural.question: Name the three types of variables in a scientific experiment.
unistructural.modelAnswer: The three types of variables are: independent variable (what you change), dependent variable (what you measure), and controlled variables (what you keep the same).

rubric.full: Correctly names all three types of variables (independent, dependent, controlled)
rubric.partial: Names two of the three types of variables correctly
rubric.minimal: Names only one type of variable correctly

multistructural.question: Describe the features of a good testable question and give an example.
multistructural.modelAnswer: A good testable question: (1) can be answered by doing an experiment, (2) identifies what will be changed and measured, (3) often starts with 'Does...', 'How does...', or 'What effect does...'. Example: 'Does the amount of light affect how fast bean seeds germinate?' This can be tested by giving seeds different amounts of light and measuring germination time.

rubric.full: Describes at least two features of testable questions and provides a relevant, testable example
rubric.partial: Describes one feature and gives an example, or describes multiple features without a clear example
rubric.minimal: States a basic feature or gives only an example without explanation

relational.question: Explain why controlled variables are essential for a fair test. Use an example to support your explanation.
relational.modelAnswer: Controlled variables are essential because they ensure only one factor is being tested at a time. Without keeping other variables constant, you cannot determine what caused any changes you observe. For example, if testing whether fertiliser helps plants grow, you must keep the amount of water, light, pot size, and soil type the same for all plants. If plants with fertiliser got more sunlight too, you wouldn't know if growth was due to the fertiliser or the extra sunlight. Controlling variables allows you to draw valid conclusions from your experiment.

rubric.full: Clearly explains the purpose of controlled variables, links this to determining cause and effect, and uses a relevant example to demonstrate understanding
rubric.partial: Explains that controlled variables are kept the same and gives an example, but doesn't clearly link to valid conclusions
rubric.minimal: Mentions keeping things the same but lacks clear explanation or relevant example

extendedAbstract.question: Design a complete investigation to test whether the colour of light affects plant growth. Include your question, hypothesis, variables, equipment, method, and explain how you would ensure reliability.
extendedAbstract.modelAnswer: Testable question: Does the colour of light affect how tall bean plants grow over two weeks? Hypothesis: Plants grown under red light will grow tallest because red wavelengths are most efficiently absorbed by chlorophyll for photosynthesis. Variables: Independent - colour of light (red, blue, green, white); Dependent - plant height in centimetres; Controlled - same plant type, pot size, soil, water amount, temperature, and duration of light exposure. Equipment: Bean seeds, identical pots with soil, coloured cellophane filters, ruler, grow lights, measuring cylinder for water. Method: (1) Plant 4 bean seeds in identical pots with same soil, (2) Place each pot under a different coloured light filter, (3) Water each plant with 50mL daily, (4) Measure and record height every 2 days for 2 weeks. Reliability: Use 3 plants per colour treatment and calculate averages, conduct the experiment in the same location to control temperature, use a timer to ensure equal light exposure time, have another student check measurements.

rubric.full: Presents a complete, well-structured investigation with clear question, hypothesis with reasoning, all three variable types correctly identified, appropriate equipment, detailed step-by-step method, and multiple strategies to ensure reliability
rubric.partial: Includes most elements but may lack detail in method, miss some controlled variables, or provide limited reliability strategies
rubric.minimal: Provides a basic outline with a question and some variables but lacks a complete method or reliability considerations

explicatoryContent.introduction: Scientific inquiry begins with curiosity and careful observation. Scientists transform their curiosity into testable questions that can be investigated systematically. In this topic, you will develop the skills to design and plan your own scientific investigations, ensuring they are fair, reliable, and meaningful.
keyPoints: Testable questions are specific and can be answered through observation or experimentation
A hypothesis is a testable prediction that includes reasoning based on scientific knowledge
Independent variables are deliberately manipulated by the investigator
Dependent variables are measured or observed in response to changes
Controlled variables are kept constant to ensure a fair test
Reliable investigations can be replicated with consistent results

vocabulary.definition: A question that can be investigated through observation or experimentation
A testable prediction about the outcome of an investigation, often including reasoning
The variable deliberately changed by the investigator
The variable measured or observed that responds to changes in the independent variable
Variables kept constant to ensure a fair and valid test
An investigation where only the independent variable is changed
Able to be repeated by others following the same method
Producing consistent results when repeated
Actually measuring or testing what was intended

analogies.analogy: Imagine comparing two runners to see who is faster. For a fair race, both runners must start at the same time, run the same distance, on the same surface, in the same conditions. If one runner had a head start or ran downhill, the race wouldn't be fair. Scientific experiments work the same way - you must keep all conditions equal except the one thing you're testing.

sections.title: From Observation to Question
sections.content: Science begins with observation. When you notice something interesting or puzzling, you can turn that observation into a question. The best scientific questions are specific and testable. 'Why do plants grow?' is too broad, but 'Does the amount of water affect how quickly bean seeds germinate?' can be tested. Good questions often focus on the relationship between two factors.

sections.title: Developing Strong Hypotheses
sections.content: A hypothesis goes beyond a simple guess. It should predict what will happen AND explain why, based on what you already know. For example: 'If plants are given more fertiliser, then they will grow taller because fertiliser provides nutrients needed for growth.' This structure (If... then... because...) helps you write complete hypotheses.

sections.title: Identifying Variables
sections.content: Every investigation involves variables - factors that can change. The independent variable is what you deliberately change to see its effect. The dependent variable is what you measure or observe - it 'depends' on the independent variable. Controlled variables are all the other factors you keep the same so your test is fair.

sections.title: Planning Replicable Methods
sections.content: A good method is like a recipe - someone else should be able to follow it exactly and get similar results. Include specific quantities, times, and measurements. Number your steps in order. Think about what equipment you'll need and how you'll record your results. Consider how many trials you'll do to ensure reliability.

sections.title: Selecting Equipment
sections.content: Choose equipment that is appropriate for what you need to measure. Consider the precision needed - a metre rule might work for some experiments, but others need millimetre accuracy. Think about the range of measurements expected. For example, if measuring small volumes, a graduated cylinder is more accurate than a measuring jug.

caseStudy.title: Investigating Seed Germination
caseStudy.scenario: Year 8 student Marcus observed that seeds in his grandmother's garden seemed to sprout faster in warmer weather. He decided to investigate this observation scientifically by designing a controlled experiment.
observations: Marcus formulated his question: 'Does temperature affect the germination rate of wheat seeds?'
He developed a hypothesis: 'If wheat seeds are kept at warmer temperatures, they will germinate faster because enzymes involved in germination work more efficiently at warmer temperatures'
He identified his variables: Independent - temperature (15°C, 20°C, 25°C); Dependent - days until germination; Controlled - seed type, water amount, light, container size
He placed 10 seeds in each of three locations with different temperatures
He checked the seeds daily and recorded the number germinated in a data table

questions.question: Why did Marcus use 10 seeds at each temperature instead of just one?
questions.answer: Using multiple seeds increases reliability. Individual seeds might have variations, but averaging results from 10 seeds gives a more accurate picture of how temperature affects germination.

questions.question: What makes Marcus's hypothesis a strong hypothesis?
questions.answer: It includes a clear prediction (seeds will germinate faster at warmer temperatures) AND scientific reasoning (enzymes work more efficiently at warmer temperatures).

questions.question: Why is it important that Marcus used the same type of seeds for all temperatures?
questions.answer: Using the same seed type is a controlled variable. Different seed types might naturally germinate at different rates, so using the same type ensures any difference in germination is due to temperature, not the seed variety.

questions.question: How could Marcus improve the reliability of his investigation?
questions.answer: He could repeat the entire experiment multiple times, use even more seeds at each temperature, or have another person independently check and record observations.

caseStudy.realWorldConnection: Agricultural scientists use similar investigations to determine optimal growing conditions for crops. Understanding how temperature affects germination helps farmers decide the best time to plant seeds for maximum crop yield.
caseStudy.modelAnalysis: Marcus's investigation demonstrates the key elements of scientific inquiry: observation leading to a question, a hypothesis based on scientific knowledge, carefully identified variables, and a systematic method that can be replicated.

remember.question: Which variable is measured or observed in an experiment?
options: Independent variable
Controlled variable
Dependent variable
Constant variable

feedback.correct: Correct! The dependent variable is what you measure or observe - it 'depends' on changes to the independent variable.
feedback.incorrect: The dependent variable is the one you measure or observe to see if it changes in response to the independent variable.

remember.question: What does 'replicable' mean in scientific investigations?
options: The results are always correct
The experiment can be repeated by others
The equipment is expensive
The hypothesis is proven true

feedback.correct: That's right! A replicable investigation is one that can be repeated by other people following the same method.
feedback.incorrect: Replicable means the experiment can be repeated by others using the same method to check if they get similar results.

understand.question: Why should a hypothesis include both a prediction AND reasoning?
options: To make it longer
Because the teacher requires it
So it shows what you expect and why, based on scientific knowledge
To make it harder to test

feedback.correct: Exactly! Including reasoning shows you've based your prediction on scientific understanding, not just a random guess.
feedback.incorrect: A good hypothesis includes reasoning to show your prediction is based on scientific knowledge, not just a guess.

understand.question: What is the relationship between reliability and repeated trials?
options: More trials make results less reliable
Repeated trials help confirm that results are consistent
One trial is always enough if done correctly
Repeated trials only matter if results are unexpected

feedback.correct: Correct! Repeating trials helps show that your results are consistent and not due to chance or errors.
feedback.incorrect: Repeated trials increase reliability by showing that results are consistent across multiple attempts.

apply.question: An investigation tests whether the type of soil affects plant growth. Which would be appropriate controlled variables?
options: Soil type and plant type
Water amount, light, pot size, and plant species
Plant height and soil colour
The researcher and the location

feedback.correct: Yes! These factors should all be kept the same so any difference in plant growth can be attributed to the soil type.
feedback.incorrect: Controlled variables are factors kept constant. Water, light, pot size, and plant species should all be the same for each soil type tested.

apply.question: You observe that ice seems to melt faster on metal surfaces than on wooden ones. Which is the best testable question?
options: Why is metal cold?
Does the material a surface is made of affect how fast ice melts on it?
Is ice interesting?
What is the best surface?

feedback.correct: This question is specific, testable, and directly relates to your observation about ice melting on different surfaces.
feedback.incorrect: A good testable question is specific and can be investigated experimentally. Think about what you observed and what you could measure.

analyse.question: A student tested the effect of salt on ice melting time. They used different amounts of salt but also used ice cubes of different sizes. What is the problem with this investigation?
options: Salt doesn't affect ice
They should have used sugar instead
Two variables were changed, making it not a fair test
Ice cubes are difficult to use

feedback.correct: Exactly! By changing both salt amount and ice cube size, the student cannot determine which factor affected the melting time.
feedback.incorrect: When designing fair tests, only one variable should be changed. Here, both salt amount and ice cube size were different.

analyse.question: Examine this method step: 'Add some water and wait a while.' What is wrong with this instruction?
options: Nothing is wrong
It lacks specific quantities and times that would allow replication
Water shouldn't be added
Waiting is not scientific

feedback.correct: Correct! 'Some' and 'a while' are too vague. The method should specify exact amounts (e.g., 100 mL) and times (e.g., 5 minutes) for replication.
feedback.incorrect: Good methods need specific measurements and times. 'Some water' and 'a while' don't tell others exactly what to do.

evaluate.question: A student's hypothesis stated that red flowers would attract more bees. After observation, they found bees preferred yellow flowers. What should the student do?
options: Change the data to support the hypothesis
Accept that the evidence doesn't support the hypothesis and report actual findings
Only report the red flower data
Conclude that bees are unreliable

feedback.correct: Correct! Scientists report their actual findings, even when they don't support the hypothesis. This can lead to new understanding.
feedback.incorrect: In science, we accept and report actual findings. A hypothesis not being supported is still valuable information.

evaluate.question: Which is the most important improvement for an investigation where results varied significantly between trials?
options: Use more colourful graphs
Identify and control additional variables that may have affected results
Ignore the varied results
Only report the best results

feedback.correct: Yes! Variable results often indicate that something wasn't controlled properly. Identifying and controlling these factors improves reliability.
feedback.incorrect: When results vary significantly, it usually means some variable wasn't controlled properly. Finding and controlling this improves the investigation.

create.question: Which hypothesis best demonstrates scientific reasoning for an investigation about water temperature and dissolving rate?
options: Hot water dissolves things
I think warm water will dissolve sugar faster because I've seen it happen at home
If water temperature increases, then sugar will dissolve faster because higher temperatures provide more kinetic energy to particles, increasing the rate of dissolution
Sugar dissolves in water sometimes

feedback.correct: Excellent! This hypothesis includes a clear if-then prediction and scientific reasoning using knowledge about kinetic energy and particles.
feedback.incorrect: The best hypothesis includes a specific prediction (if-then) AND scientific reasoning explaining why this is expected.

create.question: When planning an investigation, what should you consider first?
options: What colour your poster will be
Whether your question can actually be tested with available resources
How you will celebrate when you finish
What marks you want to achieve

feedback.correct: That's right! Before detailed planning, you need to ensure your question is testable and you have the resources to investigate it.
feedback.incorrect: The first consideration should be whether your question is actually testable with the equipment, time, and resources you have.

unistructural.question: List the three types of variables in a scientific investigation and briefly describe each one.
unistructural.modelAnswer: 1. Independent variable: the factor deliberately changed by the investigator. 2. Dependent variable: the factor measured or observed in response to changes. 3. Controlled variables: factors kept constant to ensure a fair test.

rubric.full: Correctly identifies and describes all three variable types with accurate descriptions
rubric.partial: Identifies all three variables but descriptions are incomplete or one variable is incorrect
rubric.minimal: Identifies one or two variables correctly with limited description

multistructural.question: Explain the difference between a testable and non-testable question. Provide an example of each.
multistructural.modelAnswer: A testable question can be investigated through observation or experimentation and involves measurable factors. For example: 'Does the colour of light affect plant growth?' This can be tested by growing plants under different coloured lights and measuring their height. A non-testable question cannot be answered through scientific investigation, often because it involves opinions, values, or things that cannot be measured. For example: 'Which flower is the most beautiful?' This involves personal opinion and cannot be measured scientifically.

rubric.full: Clearly explains both testable and non-testable questions with appropriate examples for each
rubric.partial: Explains both types but examples are weak, or one type is explained well with a good example while the other is limited
rubric.minimal: Provides basic distinction or only addresses one type adequately

relational.question: Explain how the elements of a well-planned investigation (question, hypothesis, variables, method) work together to produce reliable and valid results.
relational.modelAnswer: A well-planned investigation has interconnected elements that ensure reliable and valid results. The testable question defines what is being investigated and guides all other elements. The hypothesis makes a prediction based on the question and provides direction for the investigation. The variables clarify what will be changed (independent), measured (dependent), and controlled. The method outlines specific steps that operationalise these variables. When the method correctly controls all variables except the independent variable, the investigation is valid because it actually tests what it intended. When the method is detailed enough for replication and includes multiple trials, results become reliable because they are consistent. If any element is weak, it affects the whole investigation - a vague question leads to an unfocused hypothesis, poorly identified variables lead to an unfair test, and a vague method cannot be replicated.

rubric.full: Explains how all elements connect and contribute to reliability and validity, with clear understanding of how weaknesses in one element affect others
rubric.partial: Explains connections between most elements and mentions reliability or validity, but connections are not fully developed
rubric.minimal: Lists elements and mentions they are connected but doesn't clearly explain how they work together

extendedAbstract.question: Design a complete investigation to test a question of your choice. Your design should include: a testable question, hypothesis with reasoning, variables (all three types), equipment list, detailed method, and strategies to ensure reliability and validity. Justify your choices.
extendedAbstract.modelAnswer: Investigation: Effect of Caffeine on Reaction Time. Question: Does caffeine consumption affect human reaction time? Hypothesis: If a person consumes caffeine, then their reaction time will decrease (faster reactions) because caffeine is a stimulant that increases alertness and neural activity. Variables: Independent - caffeine consumption (with/without); Dependent - reaction time in milliseconds; Controlled - same participants, same test, same time of day, same testing environment, no other stimulants consumed. Equipment: Online reaction time test, stopwatch backup, caffeine tablets (100mg standardised dose), data recording sheets, consent forms. Method: (1) Recruit 20 volunteer participants aged 15-16, (2) Obtain informed consent, (3) On day 1, test all participants' reaction time using online test - 5 attempts each, record average, (4) Randomly assign participants to caffeine or placebo group, (5) On day 2, same time, caffeine group receives 100mg caffeine, placebo group receives identical-looking placebo, (6) Wait 30 minutes for absorption, (7) Test reaction time again - 5 attempts, record average, (8) Calculate change in reaction time for each participant. Reliability strategies: Using 20 participants reduces individual variation, 5 reaction tests averaged per person reduces measurement error, standardised caffeine dose and timing ensures consistency. Validity strategies: Placebo control group eliminates expectation effects, same test used throughout eliminates test variation, controlling time of day eliminates tiredness variation. Justifications: This design uses both experimental controls and sufficient sample sizes to produce meaningful results. The placebo group is particularly important because people might react faster simply because they expect to, not because of actual caffeine effects.

rubric.full: Presents a sophisticated, complete investigation with all elements, clear justifications for choices, and demonstrates understanding of how to address threats to reliability and validity
rubric.partial: Includes all major elements with some justification, but may lack depth in validity/reliability strategies or some justifications are missing
rubric.minimal: Provides basic investigation structure but missing significant elements or lacks justification for choices

explicatoryContent.introduction: Scientific inquiry is a systematic approach to understanding the natural world. It involves formulating questions that can be investigated, making predictions based on existing knowledge, designing investigations that control variables, and collecting reliable data. Mastering these skills enables you to conduct meaningful investigations that contribute to scientific knowledge.
keyPoints: Scientific questions should be specific, measurable, and achievable within available constraints
Hypotheses identify the expected relationship between independent and dependent variables
The independent variable is manipulated, the dependent variable is measured, and controlled variables are kept constant
Fair tests require only the independent variable to change between experimental conditions
Reproducibility requires detailed methods that can be followed exactly by others
Equipment selection affects the precision and reliability of data collected

vocabulary.definition: A question that can be answered through scientific observation or experimentation
A testable statement predicting the relationship between independent and dependent variables
The variable systematically manipulated by the investigator
The variable measured or observed in response to changes in the independent variable
Variables held constant to ensure changes in the dependent variable are due to the independent variable
An investigation where only the independent variable differs between experimental conditions
The ability of an investigation to be repeated with consistent results by different investigators
The degree of consistency between repeated measurements
How close a measurement is to the true or accepted value
Consistent errors that affect all measurements in the same way

analogies.analogy: Imagine throwing darts at a dartboard. If all your darts cluster tightly together but miss the bullseye, you are precise but not accurate. If your darts are scattered around the bullseye, averaging near the centre, you might be accurate on average but not precise. The goal is both - all darts clustering at the bullseye, which represents measurements that are both consistent (precise) and correct (accurate).

sections.title: Formulating Investigable Questions
sections.content: Effective scientific questions arise from careful observations and identify a relationship to be tested. They should be specific enough to investigate within practical constraints (time, equipment, safety), yet significant enough to produce meaningful findings. Consider whether your question can be answered through observation or experiment, and whether you can measure the outcomes. Questions should specify the variables involved, such as 'How does [independent variable] affect [dependent variable] in [context]?'

sections.title: Constructing Testable Hypotheses
sections.content: A well-constructed hypothesis goes beyond prediction to identify the expected relationship between variables. The 'If...then...because...' structure helps ensure completeness: 'If [independent variable changes in this way], then [dependent variable will change in this way], because [scientific reasoning].' The reasoning should draw on relevant scientific concepts and prior knowledge. A good hypothesis is falsifiable - it can be proven wrong by evidence.

sections.title: Understanding Variables and Fair Tests
sections.content: In any investigation, the independent variable is what you change deliberately to see its effect. The dependent variable is what you measure or observe - its value 'depends' on the independent variable. Controlled variables are all factors that must remain constant to ensure the investigation is valid. A fair test requires that only the independent variable differs between experimental conditions. If multiple factors change, you cannot determine which caused any observed effects.

sections.title: Designing Reproducible Methods
sections.content: A reproducible method provides enough detail that another investigator could repeat your investigation exactly. This includes specific quantities, conditions, timing, and procedures. Consider sample size (how many replicates or trials), the range and intervals of your independent variable, and how you will record data. Include safety considerations and any ethical requirements. A good test of your method is whether someone unfamiliar with your investigation could follow it successfully.

sections.title: Selecting Appropriate Equipment
sections.content: Equipment selection should match the requirements of your investigation. Consider the precision needed - measuring a plant's height to the nearest millimetre might be appropriate, but measuring bacterial growth might require specialised tools. Consider the range of your measurements and whether your equipment can accommodate it. Think about potential sources of error and how to minimise them. Document your equipment choices and justify why they are appropriate for your investigation.

caseStudy.title: Investigating Osmosis in Plant Cells
caseStudy.scenario: A team of Year 8 students wanted to investigate how the concentration of a salt solution affects the mass of potato tissue. They designed an investigation to explore osmosis in living cells.
observations: The team formulated their question: 'How does the concentration of sodium chloride solution affect the mass change of potato cylinders?'

Their hypothesis stated: 'If potato cylinders are placed in solutions of increasing salt concentration, then they will lose more mass, because water will move out of the cells by osmosis down the concentration gradient'

They identified variables: Independent - salt concentration (0%, 5%, 10%, 15%, 20%); Dependent - percentage change in mass; Controlled - potato variety, cylinder size, solution volume, temperature, duration
They cut 15 identical potato cylinders (3 per concentration) using a cork borer
Each cylinder was weighed before and after 30 minutes in its solution
Results were recorded in a table and percentage mass change was calculated

questions.question: Why did the students calculate percentage mass change rather than just recording the final mass?
questions.answer: Percentage change accounts for any small variations in initial mass between cylinders, allowing for fair comparison. It shows the relative change rather than absolute values.

questions.question: Explain why using a cork borer to cut cylinders is important for this investigation.
questions.answer: A cork borer produces cylinders of uniform diameter, controlling surface area and volume. If cylinders varied in size, this would affect how much water could move in or out, making the comparison unfair.

questions.question: The students used three cylinders at each concentration. Explain why this improves the investigation.
questions.answer: Using three replicates at each concentration improves reliability by allowing anomalies to be identified and averages to be calculated. Single measurements could be affected by random variation or errors.

questions.question: What additional controlled variable might the students need to consider?
questions.answer: The age/freshness of the potato, the time between cutting and placing in solution, the depth of immersion, and whether the solutions were stirred could all affect results and should be controlled.

caseStudy.realWorldConnection: Understanding osmosis is crucial in agriculture (managing soil salinity), food preservation (using salt or sugar to draw water from cells), and medicine (ensuring IV fluids have appropriate concentrations to avoid damaging blood cells).
caseStudy.modelAnalysis: This investigation demonstrates good experimental design: a clear question with identifiable variables, a hypothesis based on scientific understanding of osmosis, multiple concentration levels for the independent variable, replication for reliability, appropriate equipment for consistent measurements, and calculated values that allow fair comparison.

remember.question: What is the purpose of controlled variables in an investigation?
options: To make the experiment more interesting
To ensure only the independent variable affects the dependent variable
To reduce the amount of equipment needed
To speed up the experiment

feedback.correct: Correct! Controlled variables are kept constant so that any changes in the dependent variable can be attributed to changes in the independent variable.
feedback.incorrect: Controlled variables ensure a fair test by keeping all factors constant except the independent variable.

remember.question: Which term describes measurements that are consistent when repeated?
options: Accurate
Precise
Valid
Reliable

feedback.correct: That's right! Precision refers to the consistency of measurements - how close repeated measurements are to each other.
feedback.incorrect: Precision describes how consistent repeated measurements are with each other.

understand.question: Why is it important for a hypothesis to be falsifiable?
options: So the hypothesis can be proven definitely true
So the experiment is easier to conduct
So evidence can potentially show the hypothesis is incorrect
So the hypothesis sounds more scientific

feedback.correct: Exactly! A falsifiable hypothesis can be tested because it's possible for evidence to show it's wrong. This is fundamental to scientific inquiry.
feedback.incorrect: Falsifiability means evidence could potentially prove the hypothesis wrong. If there's no way to disprove it, it can't truly be tested scientifically.

understand.question: What is the difference between reproducibility and reliability?
options: They mean exactly the same thing
Reproducibility refers to others being able to repeat the investigation; reliability refers to getting consistent results
Reliability is about equipment; reproducibility is about methods
Reproducibility is more important than reliability

feedback.correct: Correct! Reproducibility means others can repeat your investigation using your method. Reliability means getting consistent results when the investigation is repeated.
feedback.incorrect: Reproducibility relates to whether others can repeat your investigation. Reliability relates to whether results are consistent upon repetition.

apply.question: A student wants to investigate how light intensity affects the rate of photosynthesis in pondweed. What would be the most appropriate dependent variable?
options: The distance of the light source from the pondweed
The number of oxygen bubbles produced per minute
The colour of the pondweed
The size of the container

feedback.correct: Yes! Oxygen bubbles are a product of photosynthesis, so counting bubbles per minute measures the rate of photosynthesis.
feedback.incorrect: The dependent variable should measure the outcome - in this case, the rate of photosynthesis. Oxygen production is a measurable indicator of photosynthesis rate.

apply.question: For an investigation measuring the effect of temperature on enzyme activity, which would be the most appropriate equipment for controlling temperature?
options: A beaker of cold water
A water bath with a thermostat
A thermometer only
A heating pad without temperature control

feedback.correct: Correct! A thermostatically controlled water bath maintains a constant, precise temperature, which is essential for controlling this variable.
feedback.incorrect: To control temperature precisely, you need equipment that maintains a constant temperature. A thermostatically controlled water bath does this effectively.

analyse.question: A student's results showed that larger paper helicopters took longer to fall. However, the larger helicopters were also made from thicker paper. Why does this present a problem for the investigation?
options: Thicker paper is more expensive
The helicopters were too large
Two variables (size and paper thickness) changed together, preventing valid conclusions
Paper helicopters don't work properly

feedback.correct: Exactly! When two variables change together (confounding variables), it's impossible to determine which one caused the observed effect.
feedback.incorrect: When two variables change together, they are 'confounded' - you can't tell which one caused the effect on fall time.

analyse.question: An investigation used one value of the independent variable with ten repeated trials. What is the limitation of this approach?
options: Ten trials is too many
There is no variation in the independent variable, so no relationship can be identified
Repeated trials are unnecessary
The equipment would break after too many trials

feedback.correct: Correct! To identify a relationship, the independent variable must be varied across a range of values. Without this variation, you can only describe conditions at one point.
feedback.incorrect: To investigate a relationship, you need to vary the independent variable across multiple values to see how the dependent variable responds.

evaluate.question: A student claims their investigation was valid because they obtained the same results three times. Is this claim correct?
options: Yes, repeated results always indicate validity
No, validity relates to whether the investigation tested what it intended to test, not just consistency
Yes, three is the minimum for validity
No, they needed at least five repetitions

feedback.correct: Correct! Repeated consistent results indicate reliability, not validity. Validity means the investigation actually tested what it intended to test (appropriate variables, fair test, etc.).
feedback.incorrect: Consistent results indicate reliability (consistency), not validity. Validity is about whether the investigation actually tested what was intended.

evaluate.question: Which modification would most improve an investigation where results varied widely between trials?
options: Using brighter colours for the data table
Identifying and controlling additional variables that may have affected outcomes
Removing the outliers from the data
Repeating only the trials that gave expected results

feedback.correct: Yes! Wide variation often indicates uncontrolled variables. Identifying and controlling these would improve reliability.
feedback.incorrect: Wide variation in results suggests some variable wasn't properly controlled. Finding and controlling this factor improves the investigation.

create.question: Which method step is most appropriately written for reproducibility?
options: Heat the solution until it feels warm
Add a small amount of acid to the test tube
Using a 50 mL graduated cylinder, measure exactly 25 mL of 0.1 M hydrochloric acid and transfer to a labelled test tube
Mix the chemicals together properly

feedback.correct: Excellent! This step specifies exact equipment, precise quantities, and clear actions that another person could replicate exactly.
feedback.incorrect: For reproducibility, methods need specific quantities, exact equipment, and precise instructions. Vague terms like 'small amount' or 'properly' don't allow exact replication.

create.question: When designing an investigation to test multiple values of an independent variable, which approach is most appropriate?
options: Test only two extreme values
Choose random values without any pattern
Select values at regular intervals across a relevant range
Test as many values as possible regardless of time

feedback.correct: That's right! Regular intervals across a range allow you to identify patterns and relationships in the data effectively.
feedback.incorrect: Selecting values at regular intervals across a range allows clear identification of patterns and relationships between variables.

unistructural.question: Define the terms 'accuracy' and 'precision' in the context of scientific measurement.
unistructural.modelAnswer: Accuracy refers to how close a measurement is to the true or accepted value - it indicates correctness. Precision refers to how consistent measurements are when repeated - it indicates reproducibility of results. A measurement can be precise without being accurate (consistently wrong) or accurate on average without being precise (scattered around the true value).

rubric.full: Clearly defines both terms with correct distinctions between them
rubric.partial: Defines both terms but distinction is unclear, or one definition is incomplete
rubric.minimal: Provides only one correct definition or confuses the terms

multistructural.question: Describe three key features that distinguish a well-designed scientific investigation from a poorly-designed one.
multistructural.modelAnswer: A well-designed investigation has: (1) A clearly defined testable question and hypothesis that identifies variables and predicted relationships. (2) Properly controlled variables, with only the independent variable changing between conditions, ensuring a fair test that produces valid results. (3) A detailed, replicable method including specific quantities, conditions, and procedures that allows others to reproduce the investigation and verify findings. Additional features include appropriate sample sizes for reliability, suitable equipment selection for accurate data collection, and consideration of safety and ethical requirements.

rubric.full: Identifies and explains three distinct features of good investigation design with clear explanations of why each matters
rubric.partial: Identifies three features but explanations lack depth, or only two features are explained well
rubric.minimal: Lists features without adequate explanation or only addresses one feature properly

relational.question: Explain how sample size and replication work together to improve the reliability and validity of an investigation. Use an example to illustrate your answer.
relational.modelAnswer: Sample size and replication work together to minimise the impact of random variation and error, thereby improving confidence in results. Larger sample sizes reduce the influence of individual variation - for example, testing the effect of a fertiliser on 50 plants rather than 5 plants reduces the chance that natural variation between individual plants will skew results. Replication (repeating trials) allows identification of anomalies and calculation of averages, making results more reliable. In the fertiliser example, measuring each plant's height three times and averaging reduces measurement error. Together, these strategies ensure that observed patterns represent genuine effects rather than chance occurrences. Validity is improved because with sufficient replication and sample size, the relationship between variables can be determined with greater confidence.

rubric.full: Explains both concepts and their interaction, links clearly to reliability and validity, and uses an appropriate example
rubric.partial: Explains both concepts with some link to reliability, but the relationship between them or the example is underdeveloped
rubric.minimal: Mentions both concepts but doesn't explain how they work together or lacks a clear example

extendedAbstract.question: Critically evaluate the following investigation design and suggest improvements: 'To test if music helps plants grow, one plant was played classical music for a week while another plant was placed in a quiet room. At the end, the first plant looked healthier.'
extendedAbstract.modelAnswer: Critical evaluation: This investigation has significant design flaws affecting validity and reliability. (1) Sample size: Using only one plant per condition means individual plant variation cannot be distinguished from treatment effects. (2) Subjective measurement: 'Looked healthier' is not objective or measurable; no quantitative data was collected. (3) Uncontrolled variables: The investigation doesn't control for light, temperature, water, or pot conditions between rooms. (4) Limited duration and measurement: One week may be insufficient to detect growth differences. (5) Lack of replication: No repeated trials or measurements. (6) No hypothesis: The investigation lacks a clear prediction with scientific reasoning. Improvements: (1) Use multiple plants (minimum 10) per condition, randomly assigned. (2) Use quantitative measurements: height in mm, leaf count, leaf area, or biomass. (3) Conduct in the same location with controlled conditions; if different rooms are necessary, control for all environmental variables. (4) Extend duration to several weeks with regular measurements. (5) Include a silent control group (not just a 'quiet room' which may differ in other ways). (6) State a hypothesis with reasoning, such as: 'If plants are exposed to classical music, they will grow taller because sound vibrations may stimulate cellular activity.' (7) Blind the measurement - have someone who doesn't know which plants received music take the measurements.

rubric.full: Identifies multiple specific flaws in the investigation design, explains why each is problematic using scientific reasoning, and proposes detailed, practical improvements that would address each flaw
rubric.partial: Identifies several flaws and proposes improvements but explanations of why they are problematic or how improvements address them lack depth
rubric.minimal: Identifies some basic flaws or proposes improvements but does not clearly connect problems to solutions or lacks scientific reasoning

reflectionQuestions: What aspects of planning investigations do you now find easier, and what remains challenging?
How would you explain the importance of fair testing to someone who thought you could just change whatever you wanted in an experiment?
How might these investigation skills be valuable in a science-related career you find interesting?

studentReflection.connectionToLife: The skills of systematic inquiry are essential in scientific research, medical trials, product development, and quality control across industries. Even in daily life, from cooking to troubleshooting technology problems, the ability to identify variables and test ideas systematically helps you solve problems effectively and evaluate claims critically.

whatYouWillLearn.coreLearning: You will develop advanced skills in experimental design, including formulating sophisticated research questions, developing theoretically-grounded hypotheses, implementing rigorous variable control, and designing investigations with attention to validity, reliability, and methodological precision.
learningIntentions: I can formulate complex, investigable research questions that identify relationships between multiple variables
I can develop hypotheses grounded in scientific theory that make specific, quantitative predictions
I can implement comprehensive variable control strategies and identify potential confounding factors
I can design investigations with appropriate controls, sample sizes, and methodological rigour

successCriteria: I can construct research questions that specify variables and expected relationships with operational definitions
